awd_titl_txt: The Macroeconomics of Second-Best Climate Policies
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds research that uses economic theory and on the economic and environmental consequences of “non-traditional” environmental policies designed to reduce carbon dioxide emissions. While most economic studies of carbon reduction policies have focused on taxing fossil fuels, this research project focuses on policies that subsidies for the production of renewable energy and mandates for the use of clean energy.  The research will use theoretical modelling, a large data set, and innovative empirical methods to investigate how subsidies and mandates can be designed to reduce emissions at the lowest cost to economic growth and efficiency compared to other forms of fuels.  In addition, the project will estimate the impact of the Inflation Reduction Act as well as the impact of the Clean Power Plan on both carbon emissions and economic growth.  The results of this research project will provide major inputs into policies to reduce carbon emissions, while spurring economic growth and establish the US as a global leader in carbon reduction policies.

This award funds a research agenda to study the efficiency of carbon reduction policies other than those that tax fossil fuels.  The project will develop and estimate a quantitative, dynamic model of the macroeconomy and the environment to test the efficiency of “second best” carbon policies. The model extends the standard modeling framework in two ways: first, it will allow the price elasticity of energy demand to differ in the short-, medium- and long-run because of the differential effects of carbon and subsidies for renewables on the price of energy; in addition, the model will  incorporate the value of public funds raised from carbon taxes.  The researchers will use a large data set and different econometric methods to estimate the model and compare it to the results from emission tax policies.  The estimates will then be used to analyze recent policy proposals such as the Inflation Reduction Act and the Clean Power Plan.  The results of this research project will provide major inputs into policies to reduce carbon emissions, while spurring economic growth and establish the US as a global leader in carbon reduction policies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Climate change poses significant risks to economies around the world. Economists have long studied policies meant to reduce carbon emissions ("mitigation policies"). Most macroeconomic analyses of mitigation policies focus on carbon taxes, because they limit emissions at the lowest cost to overall economic output. Policymakers, however, consider and implement a wider set of policy options. Indeed, climate scientists, environmental activists, and pundits regularly criticize economic analyses of climate change as irrelevant to ongoing policy discussions, because the analyses cover such a narrow range of policy options.

I explore the effectiveness of climate policies beyond carbon taxes ("second-best" policies) in macroeconomic models. My focus is on subsidies for carbon-free energy, which are a key part of the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) passed in 2022. The findings from this research are reported in two academic papers: Casey et al. (2023) and Casey and Gao (2024). Both papers are currently under review by journals that specialize in environmental economics.

In Casey et al. (2023), we provide a framework for macroeconomists to think about clean energy subsidies. Relative to first-best policies, the shortcoming of clean energy subsidies is that they promote increases in energy use, undermining emissions reductions and pulling economic resources away from other valuable activities. We show that the best possible clean energy subsidy is the product of two terms: the external cost of dirty energy and the rate at which new clean energy displaces dirty energy. The best possible ("Pigouvian") carbon tax would be equal to the external cost of dirty energy. In a standard macroeconomic model, two key factors determine how much clean energy displaces dirty energy: (1) how easily households and firms switch to clean energy as it becomes cheaper (i.e., the elasticity of substitution), and (2) how much energy demand increases when prices drop (i.e., the price elasticity of demand). At parameter values used in the influential work of Golosov et al (2014), clean energy subsidies actually increase emissions and reduce wellbeing, because there is little switching between energy sources even as total energy use increases significantly. If clean and dirty energy are more substitutable (i.e., interchangeable), subsidies can lead to modest emissions reductions, though they remain much less cost-effective than carbon taxes. These results highlight the potential benefits of reorienting US climate policy towards carbon pricing. In addition, the results highlight the importance of policies---like those supporting energy storage and transmission---that complement clean energy subsidies by making clean and dirty energy more substitutable.

In Casey and Gao (2024), we extend this work by studying clean energy subsidies in a model with a more realistic representation of the price elasticity of demand for energy services. Using U.S. data, we estimate impulse response functions that characterize how energy use responds to decreases in energy prices. In the short run, energy use does not react to changes in price, but there is a large increase in energy use in the long run. As a result, clean energy subsidies can significantly reduce dirty energy use and carbon emissions in the short and medium run, even in cases where they increase emissions in the long run. This finding differs significantly from leading climate-economy models (e.g., Golosov et al., 2014), where there is no distinction between the short- and long-run price elasticity of demand for energy services. This shows that clean energy subsidies are more effective than standard models predict, particularly for short-run emissions reductions that provide time for new carbon-free technologies to develop.

The findings from this project have already contributed to discussions of environmental policymaking. Casey et al. (2023) was cited in the 2024 Economic Report of the President (Council of Economic Advisors, 2024). Both papers have been presented at numerous conferences and seminars held by academic departments and policy institutions. This includes the European Commission, thel Federal Reserve Banks of Dallas, Kansas City, and San Francisco, Brown University, UC Santa Barbara, and conference sessions hosted by the Association of Environmental and Resource Economists. 

 

References:

- Casey, G., Jeon, W., & Traeger, C. (2023). The Macroeconomics of Clean Energy Subsidies. CESifo Working Paper No. 10828.

- Casey, G., & Gao, Y. (2024). Energy Efficiency Dynamics and Climate Policy. CESifo Working Paper No. 11303.

- Council of Economic Advisers (2024). “Accelerating the Clean Energy Transition” in the 2024 Economic Report of the President.

- Golosov, M., Hassler, J., Krusell, P., and Tsyvinski, A. (2014). Optimal taxes on fossil fuel in general equilibrium. Econometrica, 82(1), 41-88.
